metadata.background_text:
Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.
metadata.question: What does the author think is not possible to ensure?
metadata.first_debater_answer: Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments
metadata.second_debater_answer: More unemployed people will be linked with greater savings
metadata.debate_identifier: Vulgar Keynesians_What does the author think is not possible to ensure?

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What does the author think is not possible to ensure?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "More unemployed people will be linked with greater savings".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for Debater_A’s Position (“Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments” is what the author holds is not possible to ensure)

1. My Proposed Answer Matches the Author’s Criterion of “Impossible to Ensure”  
   a. The question asks: “What does the author think is not possible to ensure?”  
   b. I answer: That reduced consumer spending (i.e., higher savings) will, without Fed intervention, automatically translate into higher investment and lower unemployment.  
   c. This is exactly what the author labels the “paradox of thrift,” “widow’s cruse,” and other “vulgar Keynesian” ideas as unworkable except in circumstances when interest rates are already at zero and the Fed powerless (<invalid_quote>“it is an arguable claim right now for Japan…when the rate … was less than one-tenth of 1 percent”</invalid_quote>).  
   d. The author stresses that in practice “the simple Keynesian story” only holds when the central bank cannot lower rates further; otherwise, “interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output” is false (<invalid_quote>“After all, the simple Keynesian story…in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates”</invalid_quote>).  

2. Citations Confirm This Is the “Impossible” Case  
   a. “To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth…you must argue that the Fed is impotent” (<quote>would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that</quote>). In normal times, the Fed is not impotent.  
   b. “If you want a simple model for predicting unemployment…It will be what Greenspan wants it to be” (<quote> It will be what Greenspan wants it to be,</quote>). Thus savings alone cannot dictate outcomes.  

3. Logical Coherence  
   a. If higher savings alone guaranteed higher investment, Fed policy would be irrelevant. Yet the author repeatedly emphasizes the Fed’s power (<quote>(the Fed can double the money supply in a day,</quote>) and that real-world episodes (US post-World War II growth, modern Japan) only show the paradox when rates are at zero.  
   b. The public debate (e.g., NAFTA) shows that policymakers ignore “paradox of thrift” arguments because they recognize—they must rely on Fed action to achieve target unemployment, not trade balances or savings rates (<quote>trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness.</quote>).  

4. Refutation of Debater_B (“More unemployed people will be linked with greater savings”)  
   a. Misreads the passage: The author concedes that in “some sufficiently long run…these theories might indeed be valid” (<invalid_quote>“in the long run they might…valid”</invalid_quote>), but he explicitly rejects them in the short and medium run because “the public’s desire to hold cash” and Fed policy means slumps only end when the Fed adjusts rates.  
   b. Ignores the author’s requirement that to sustain the “paradox” you must show Fed impotence. No evidence is given that the Fed cannot or will not lower rates. Indeed, the author says “you can hardly dispute” Fed’s power.  
   c. Contradicts the author’s own example: In the 1930s (when rates were at zero), slumps persisted despite high savings; output only recovered when monetary policy finally loosened. Thus savings alone did not end the slump.  

5. Conclusion  
   The author deems the automatic translation of higher savings into higher investment—and thus lower unemployment—impossible to ensure under normal circumstances due to the active role of central bankers. My answer precisely identifies that situation; Debater_B’s does not.

speeches.content:
My Position: The author holds that it is not possible to ensure that higher desired savings will be translated into higher investment—and hence full employment—when the “visible hand” (the Fed) cannot or will not push interest rates low enough. In such circumstances (“vulgar Keynesian” slumps), more savings lead to more unemployment (“paradox of thrift”).  

I. Support from the Text for My Answer  
1. Paradox of Thrift Requires Fed Power, Fails at Zero Bound  
  a. “Early Keynesian models” predict that higher savings cause slumps unless “the Fed will make sure that [investment] does” (paragraphs 6 and 9).  
  b. “It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. … the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to” (paragraph 12) – implying that only active Fed offset can prevent paradox.  
  c. Exception when Fed power is impotent: “The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent” (paragraph 13).  

2. Unemployment and Savings Link When Fed Passive  
  a. The author explicitly cites the 1930s and Japan as demonstrations that “potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate” (paragraph 13).  
  b. These are cases where “increasing savings will slow the economy—presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates” (paragraph 15).  

II. Objections to Debater_A’s Position (“Fed Always Ensures Savings→Investment”)  
1. Zero Lower Bound Problem

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.



 Here is the topic you will be debating:

speeches.content:
1. Restating the Question and My Position  
   a. The question asks “What does the author think is not possible to ensure?”  
   b. My answer: That a rise in desired savings will, by itself and without unconstrained central‐bank action, automatically translate into higher investment and thus full employment (“the paradox of thrift,” “widow’s cruse,” etc.).  

2. Textual Support for My Answer  
   a. “In reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates … If you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate … it will be what Greenspan wants it to be” (<quote> It will be what Greenspan wants it to be,</quote>, para. 8). If savings alone guaranteed outcomes, Fed policy would be redundant.  
   b. “To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth … you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent” (<quote> you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent-</quote>, para. 12). The author treats savings‐driven slumps as a curiosity only when the Fed cannot lower rates further.  
   c. “The Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to” (<quote>(the Fed can double the money supply in a day,</quote>, para. 12). This underscores that in normal times savings will be offset by rate cuts.  

3. Why Savings Alone Cannot “Ensure” Investment  
   a. The author calls the “paradox of thrift” a “vulgar Keynesian” caricature that “confuses and befogs” debate (opening). He repeatedly stresses that only when the Fed is passive or constrained (e.g., zero lower bound in the 1930s, Japan) does the paradox manifest. In any other case, “lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment” (<invalid_quote>Feb. 3 commentary</invalid_quote>, para. 15).  
   b. Public debate ignores paradox arguments (NAFTA example) because policymakers know that “the average unemployment rate … will be what the Fed wants it to be” (para. 10). If savings alone sufficed, there would be no need to debate policy levers.  

4. Refutation of Debater_B’s Position  
   a. Misreads the Text’s Scope: Debater_B claims the author believes more savings → more unemployment even when rates are positive. But the author grants that “in the long run … these theories might … be valid” and that slumps occur only when “potential savings … so high … near‐zero interest rate” (para. 13). He explicitly argues that elsewhere “the Fed will make sure” investment rises (para. 9).  
   b. Zero Lower Bound Is Not a General Case: The fact that Japan “could still pull that economy out of its funk” but chooses not to (para. 13) is called “gross malfeasance,” not a demonstration that the paradox is inherent. The author’s view is that Fed passivity, not a fundamental breakdown of rate mechanics, causes slumps. He says “you can hardly dispute [the Fed’s] power” (para. 8).  
   c. Empirical Recovery Only Follows Monetary Action: Historically, the U.S. Great Depression ended with monetary expansion and policy innovation (e.g., abandonment of gold standard), not through rising thrift alone. If savings automatically spurred investment, no activist policy would have been required.  

5. Logical Consistency  
   a. If I assert that “less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments” cannot be “ensured,” I align perfectly with the author’s emphasis on the necessity of active Fed management. Without it, savings “reduce income and also reduce investment demand” (para. 5).  
   b. My interpretation explains why “very few people outside … think about things that way” (para. 10): the public sees policy impotence or constraints and fears slumps from saving. Only when the central bank demonstrates its power does the classical vision “restore.”  

6. Conclusion  
   The author’s repeated insistence that only an unconstrained Fed can “assure” that savings translate into investment shows that, in his view, savings alone lack that power. Thus he thinks it is not possible to ensure that higher savings will, without active central‐bank intervention beyond the zero lower bound, lead to higher investment and full employment. My answer directly captures that “impossible to ensure” condition; Debater_B’s does not.

But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.    • The question asks: “What does the author think is not possible to ensure?”  
   • My answer: That higher desired savings will, on their own, be translated into higher investment and full employment in the presence of an imperfect or constrained Fed (“vulgar Keynesian” slump).  

2. Textual Evidence for My Answer  
   2.1 Zero‐Bound and Fed Impotence Cases  
     a. “The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one‐tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 13</invalid_quote>).  
        – Shows that even at near‐zero rates savings do not automatically induce investment. The author calls these “slumps” where “potential savings are so high...the Fed cannot bring the two in line.”  
     b. “Increasing savings will slow the economy—presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 15</invalid_quote>).  
        – Confirms that more savings → more unemployment when the Fed is passive or powerless.  

   2.2 Paradox Requires Fed Offset  
     a. “It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences…The Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 12</invalid_quote>).  
        – Paradox only holds if Fed does not act; ensures that without Fed intervention, higher savings will cause slumps.  

3. Objections to Debater_A’s Interpretation  
   3.1 Misunderstanding of “Impossible to Ensure”  
     a. Debater_A claims the “impossible” case is that savings won’t translate into investment unless Fed intervenes. That is exactly my answer: it is impossible to ensure the translation *without* Fed power.  
     b. Debater_A’s own citations emphasize active Fed role (<quote>It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or</quote>). If savings alone guaranteed investment, Fed actions would be redundant—contrary to the author’s insistence on Fed management.  

   3.2 Zero Lower Bound Constraints  
     a. Debater_A ignores the “near‐zero” limit: “Treasury bills was less than one‐tenth of 1 percent” is evidence that the Fed cannot reduce rates further (<invalid_quote>paragraph 13</invalid_quote>). Liquidity preference prevents negative rates.  
     b. In these cases, the author explicitly accepts the paradox: “increasing savings will slow the economy” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 15</invalid_quote>).  

   3.3 Empirical Slumps Undermining Automatic Adjustment  
     a. Great Depression lasted over a decade despite classical theories—only ended after monetary loosening.  
     b. Japan’s “lost decade” persists because the central bank was “passive,” not because savings induced investment. The author calls this “gross malfeasance” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 13</invalid_quote>).  

   3.4 Public Debate Ignores Fed Limits  
     a. NAFTA debate focused on trade jobs, not savings, because policymakers know that without Fed action, savings changes have perverse effects (<invalid_quote>paragraph 10</invalid_quote>). If savings always worked, they would cite it.  

4. Reinforcing My Interpretation  
   • The author labels the “paradox of thrift” and “widow’s cruse” as “vulgar” and “caricature” that fail except when Fed is powerless. He *questions* their validity and says they *cannot be ensured* under normal conditions.  
   • His challenge: “To justify the claim that savings are actually bad…you must argue that the Fed is impotent” (<invalid_quote>paragraph 15</invalid_quote>). This admission underscores that without Fed impotence higher savings *would* translate, but because impotence *can* persist, translation is not guaranteed.  
   • Therefore, it is *impossible to ensure* that savings alone, in all circumstances, will raise investment and employment. Only Fed power can; and Fed power may be constrained.  

5. Conclusion  
   My answer identifies exactly what the author sees as “not possible to ensure”: the automatic, savings-driven path to investment and full employment when the central bank cannot or will not lower rates further. Debater_A’s answer misreads the text by ignoring the zero‐bound constraint and by conflating “with Fed” and “without Fed.” The author’s repeated focus on cases where savings worsen slumps demonstrates that such translation *cannot* be guaranteed—hence my answer is correct.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating: Vulgar Keynesians Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment.    c. “The Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to” (<quote>(the Fed can double the money supply in a day,</quote>, para. 12). This underscores that in normal times savings will be offset by rate cuts.
